newsitem.title: GERMANY: German industry orders up again in July.
newsitem.headline: German industry orders up again in July.

text.p: German July industrial orders data published on Wednesday showed the second consecutive monthly gain, encouraging economists to predict solid overall economic growth in the third quarter after a robust spring.
Industrial orders grew by a monthly 0.6 percent after a 1.9 percent gain in June, the economics ministry said.
A rise of 0.9 percent in western Germany was undermined by what economists called a worrying 4.7 percent drop in the "new states" of former communist eastern Germany.

They said the picture emerging from early indicators for July, along with last week's business confidence survey by the Ifo institute, pointed to continued growth at a slower pace following a leap during the spring.

"The economy is going well, and will do well in the second half," said economist Holger Schmieding at Merrill Lynch in Frankfurt. "The monthly figures are distorted by major orders, but if you look at the trend it is dramatically upward."

Second quarter gross domestic product figures are due on Thursday. They are expected by economists to show a gain of 1.0-1.5 percent over the first quarter when Germany suffered from bad winter weather and output fell 0.4 percent.

The industrial orders figures came in above a plus 0.3 percent consensus forecast in a Reuter survey -- but within expectations. They followed industrial output data on Tuesday which also showed a slowdown in month-on-month growth in July from June although the growth trend extended back five months.

The orders figure was "a little better than I thought, but just barely," said Adolf Rosenstock of the Industrial Bank of Japan in Frankfurt. "Looking at output and orders data, output was below expectations, so this compensates.
"The trend development is rather stable, so this should not have policy or market implications. West Germany seems to have stabilised. We are on a moderate upward trend, but nothing spectacular."
Pan-German industrial orders were down by 0.1 percent in July on the same month a year earlier, after a two percent rise in June, according to calculations based on Bundesbank data.
Economists said the slump in east German orders could have either been caused by a gap in major orders or problems due to the summer holidays.
"The improvement is there, but we are not out of the woods yet. In the east, there are clouds on the horizon," Rosenstock said.

Gerhard Grebe of Bank Julius Baer said that the poor east German figure meant pan-German orders were below his forecast. But he expected that number to be revised up later and said he was leaving his overall view unchanged.
"My outlook is for a strong economic recovery in the second quarter, followed by a continuation at a slower pace in the third quarter," Grebe said.
Data across the board showed strong growth of over seven percent in foreign orders, while domestic orders were sluggish and slipped back by nearly three percent against June.

The fledgling economic upturn is unlikely to help employment, however. Economists expect August unemployment data due on Thursday to show continued stagnation at close to post-war record highs of just under four million.
